ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that a table should be displayed summarizing the parameterization of classification 
variables in the model for the design.
Specifies which type of coding to use for modeling effects in the design.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the values of all effects are to be coded to have maximum and minimum values of  +1 and -1, respectively.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies orthogonal coding with respect to the points in the candidate data set.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies orthogonal coding with respect to the points in the candidate data set.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the input SAS data set that contains the candidate points for the design.

[Syntax: EPSILON=ε] 
      
Specifies the smallest value ε that is considered to be nonzero for determining when the search is 
no longer yielding an improved design and when the information matrix for the design is singular. 
By default, ε = 0.00001.

[Syntax: NAMELEN=n] 
      
Specifies the length of effect names in tables and output data sets to be n characters long, where 
n is a value between 20 and 200 characters. The default length is 20 characters.
Suppresses the coding of effects in the model for the design. This option is equivalent to CODING=NONE.
Suppresses all output. This is useful when you only want the final design to be saved in a data set.

[Syntax: SEED=s] 
      
Specifies an integer used to start the pseudo-random number generator for initialization.
Specifies that the status of the search be checked at the given level, where status-level is an integer between 1 and 4, inclusive.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Checks status after each design search; the number of searches specified by the NITER= option.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Checks status after each search loop.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Checks status after each internal search loop.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Checks status after each extra internal search loop for METHOD=M_FEDOROV.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Reverses the sorting order of the classification variable.
Specifies the sorting order for the levels of classification variables.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Orders values according to their order in the input data set.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Orders values by their ascending formatted values. This order depends on your operating environment.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Orders values by descending frequency count so that levels with the most observations are listed first.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order as PROC SORT. This order  depends on your operating environment.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the parameterization method for the classification variable or variables.

[Syntax: REF=’level’ | FIRST | LAST] 
          
Specifies the reference level for PARAM=EFFECT, or PARAM=REFERENCE.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: For an individual (but not a global) variable REF= option, you can specify the level of the variable  to use as the reference level. Replace 'level' with an actual value, enclosed in quotes.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: For a global or individual variable REF= option, this designates the first ordered level as reference.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: For a global or individual variable REF= option, this designates the last ordered level as reference.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that class levels should be determined by using only up to the first 16 characters of the 
formatted values of CLASS variables.
Excludes the intercept parameter from the model.

[Syntax: PRIOR=num-list] 
          
Specifies prior precision values corresponding to groups of effects in the model. Groups of effects 
in the MODEL statement with the same prior precision must be separated by commas. Then use the PRIOR= 
option, listing as many prior precision values as there are groups of effects.

[Syntax: COVAR=SAS-data-set VAR=( variables )] 
          
Specifies a data set to use in providing a general covariance matrix for the runs.

[Syntax: VAR=( variables )] 
          
Names the variables in the data set (specified in the COVAR= option) that contain the columns of the
covariance matrix for the runs.

[Syntax: DESIGN=SAS-data-set] 
          
Specifies a data set to use in providing a general covariate model.

[Syntax: STRUCTURE=(b)k] 
          
Specifies a block design with b blocks of size k.

Specifies that the starting design is to be constructed by selecting candidates at random without 
replacement.

[Syntax: ITER=n] 
          
Specifies the number of times to repeat the search from different initial designs.

[Syntax: KEEP=m] 
          
Specifies that only the best m designs are to be retained. The value m must be less than or equal 
to the value n of the ITER= option.

Suppresses the part of the optimal blocking algorithm that exchanges treatment design points for 
candidate treatment points.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: EXAMINE <options> ; 
      
You use the EXAMINE statement to display the characteristics of a selected design.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Lists the actual points in the selected design.
Lists the information matrix X'X for the selected design.

[Syntax: NUMBER=design-number] 
          
Selects a design to examine by specifying its design-number.
Lists the variance matrix (X'X)⁻¹ for the parameter estimates for the selected design.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: GENERATE <options> ;
      
You use the GENERATE statement to customize the search for a design.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: AUGMENT=SAS-data-set] 
          
Specifies a data set that contains a design to be augmented---in other words, a set of points 
that must be contained in the design generated.
Specifies the optimality criterion used in the search.
Specifies a method for obtaining an initial design for the search procedure.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies an initial design chosen by a sequential search.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies a completely random initial design.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Syntax: PARTIAL<(m)>                                      Specifies an initial design by using a mixture of RANDOM and SEQUENTIAL methods. A small number  nr of points for the initial design are chosen at random from the candidates, and the rest of the  design points are chosen by a sequential search. You can specify the optional integer n to modify  the selection of nr.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies a data set that holds the initial design.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ITER=n] 
          
Specifies the number n of searches to make. Because local optima are common in difficult search 
problems, it is often a good idea to make several tries for the optimal design with a random or 
partially random method of initialization (see the INITDESIGN= option). By default, n = 10.
The n designs found are sorted by their respective efficiencies according to the current optimality 
criterion (see the CRITERION=option.) The most efficient design is assigned a design-number of 1, 
the second most efficient design is assigned a design-number of 2, and so on. You can then use the 
design-number in the EXAMINE and OUTPUT statements to display the characteristics of a design or to 
save a design in a data set.

[Syntax: KEEP=m] 
          
Specifies that only the best m designs are to be retained. The value m must be less than or equal 
to the value n of the ITER= option. By default m=n, so that all iterations are kept. This option 
is useful when you want to make many searches to overcome the problem of local optima but are 
interested only in the results of the best m designs.
Specifies the procedure used to search for the optimal design.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Syntax: DETMAX<(level)>               The optional level gives the maximum excursion level for the search, where level is an integer  greater than or equal to 1.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Syntax: EXCHANGE<(k)>                                      The optional k specifies the k-exchange search method of Johnson and Nachtsheim (1983), which  generalizes the modified Fedorov search algorithm of Cook and Nachtsheim (1980). Enclose the  value of k in parentheses immediately following the word EXCHANGE.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: N=n] 
          
Specifies the number of points in the final design. The default design size is 10 + p, 
where p is the number of parameters in the model.
Specifies to search for a design with the same number of points as there are parameters in the model.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: OUTPUT OUT= SAS-data-set < options > ; 
      
You use the OUTPUT statement to save a design in an output data set.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
          
Gives a name for the output data set. The OUT= data set is required in the OUTPUT statement.

[Syntax: BLOCKNAME=variable-name] 
          
Specifies the name to be given to the blocking variable in the output data set. The default 
name is BLOCK.

Selects a design to output by specifying its design-number. Designs are ordered by the value of the 
efficiency criterion that is being optimized.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Selects the design that has the highest D-efficiency value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Selects the design that has the highest A-efficiency value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Selects the design that has the highest G-efficiency value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Selects the design that has the minimum average standard error for prediction.
